title: Redesigned Jordan Henderson continues to reap the rewards from a risky approach to his manager about future midfield role
text:
It was after Spurs’ Anfield visit last season that Jordan Henderson sought a meeting with Jurgen Klopp.

Liverpool’s captain had been given a sobering glimpse of the future if he persisted as a deep-playing No 6 and felt it was time to step aside.

His reasoning was two-fold. First, despite a last-minute victory, he had toiled against Tottenham’s nimble runners, unable to dictate the tempo or link the play.

More pertinently, the game had shifted when he was replaced by Fabinho – a substitute on that occasion – who gave Liverpool’s midfield a security and control they have not surrendered since that win in March.

The wisdom and foresight of Henderson vacating a position he occupied for two years...
